title-group.article-title: A metallothionein type 2 from Avicennia marina binds to iron and mediates hydrogen peroxide balance by activation of enzyme catalase

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
A metallothionein type 2 from
Avicennia marina
binds to iron and mediates hydrogen peroxide balance by activation of enzyme catalase
Zahra Babaei-Bondarti, Azar Shahpiri ∗
Department of Biotechnology, College of Agriculture, Isfahan University of Technology, Isfahan , 84156-83111, Iran
A R T I C L E I N F O

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Metallothionein
Metal accumulation
Recombinant protein
Iron
Hydrogen peroxide tolerance
A B S T R A C T

Metallothioneins (MTs) are low molecular weight, cysteine-rich, metal-binding proteins that are important for essential metal homeostasis, protection against oxidative stress, and buffering against toxic heavy metals. In this work the gene encoding an MT type 2 from Avicennia marina (Forssk.) Vierh. (AmMT2) was cloned into pET41a and transformed into the
Escherichia coli
strain Rosetta (DE3). Following the induction with isopropyl β-D- 1- thiogalactopyranoside, AmMT2 was expressed as glutathione-S-transferase (GST)-tagged fusion protein. The accumulation of Zn 2+ , Cu 2+ , Fe 2+ , Ni 2+ and Cd 2+ for strain R-AmMT2 was 4, 8, 5.4, 2 and 1.6 fold of control strain suggesting the role of AmMT 2 in accumulation of metals. Particularly the strain R-AmMT2 was able to accumulate 30.7 mg per g dry weight. The cells expressing AmMT2 was more tolerant to hydrogen peroxide and had higher catalase (CAT) activity. To understand the mechanistic action of AmMT2 hydrogen peroxide tolerance, the activity of CAT in the
E. coli
protein extract was assayed after addition of pure Fe 2+ /GST-AmMT complex and Apo/GST-AmMT
2 in
vitro. Whereas, the activity of CAT did not change by the addition of Apo/GSTAmMT2, the activity of CAT significantly increased after addition of Fe 2+ /GST-AmMT2. These results show that AmMT2 activates CAT through Fe 2+ transfer which subsequently causes the oxidative stress tolerance.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
Orphanage
sec.p: 2.1. GST-AmMT2 was expressed in E. coli

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: The full-length coding sequence of AmMT2 with 240 bp encodes a 79 amino acid protein with a theoretical molecular weight of 7.7/4.55 (kDa)/pI. The presence of two Cys-rich regions with eight Cys residues (CCXXXCXCXXXCXCXXXCXXC) at the N-terminal and six Cys residues (CXCXXXCXCXXCXC) at the C-terminal parts, respectively, confirms that AmMT2 is classified in type 2 MTs ( Fig. 1A ). The coding sequence of AmMT2 was subcloned into the expression vector pET41a containing coding sequences for an N-terminal fusion partner of glutathione-S-transferase (GST-tag), a 6His-tag, and an S-tag (the complete tag was named GST) ( Fig. 1B ).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Following induction with IPTG, the recombinant proteins GST and GST-AmMT2 were expressed in the soluble fraction of the
E. coli cells
carrying the pET41a and pET41-AmMT2, respectively. The theoretical molecular weight/pI of GST and GST-AmMT2 were 35.5/6.3 and 40.2/ 5.7 kDa, respectively. The proteins GST and GST-AmMT2 at the correct molecular weight appeared on the SDS-PAGE as sharp bands ( Fig. 2A ).

sec.title: Orphanage
2.2. The strain R-AmMT2 is able to uptake considerable amounts of iron from culture medium
sec.p:
The strain R-AmMT2 as well as control was grown in the medium containing Zn 2+ , Cu 2+ , Fe 2+ , Ni 2+ and Cd 2+ . As shown in Fig. 3 the final cell densities (cell density after 12 h) of strain R-AmMT2 were similar to that from control ( A 600 = 1.8) when the strains were grown in the medium with no stress. However, in the presence of Zn 2+ , Cu 2+ , Fe 2+ and Ni 2+ the strain R-AmMT2 with the final OD600 of 1.38, 1.86, 1.97 and 1.53, respectively had higher OD than that of control strain. These data show that the heterologous expression of GST–AmMT2 enhances the tolerance of
E. coli cells
to Zn 2+ , Cu 2+ , Fe 2+ and Ni 2+ . Nevertheless the heterologous expression of AmMT2 did not affect on the growth rate of the
E. coli cells
in the presence of Cd 2+ .

To determine whether the enhanced of tolerance of R-AmMT2 to metals is accompanied by increasing accumulation of metal ions in these cells, the recombinant strains as well as control were grown in liquid medium supplemented with Zn 2+ , Cu 2+ , Fe 2+ , Ni 2+ and Cd 2+ ( Fig. 4 ). The concentrations of heavy metal ions in the culture medium were determined by atomic absorption at time of addition of metal (T0) and 6 h (T1) after the addition of IPTG and metals to the cultures. The concentration variations of Zn 2+ , Cu 2+ , Fe 2+ , Ni 2+ and Cd 2+ in the medium of control strain were 3 ± 0.1, 0.8 ± 0.04, 3.2 ± 0.15, 5.3 ± 0.1 and 2 ± 0.1 ppm. In comparison the changes in concentration of corresponding metal ions in the medium of R-AmMT2 were 12 ± 0.2, 8.3 ± 1, 17.5 ± 0.015, 11.1 ± 0.1 and 3.34 ± 0.01. These data show that the amount of metal ion variations in the medium of strain R-AmMT2 is significantly (P <0.01 for Zn 2+ , Cu 2+ , Fe 2+ , Ni 2+ and P <0.05 for Cd 2+) higher than that for control strain, suggesting the role of AmMT 2 in accumulation of metals.
In particular the elimination of 17.5 ppm Fe 2+ ( 30.7 mg Fe 2+ /g d.W.) by R-AmMT2 is an outstanding property of this strain.

sec.title: 2.3. The recombinant GST-AmMT2 is able to bind Fe 2+ in vitro
sec.p:
The characteristic ligand-to-metal charge transfer bands observed in the UV spectra ( 210–360 nm ) recorded after incubating the recombinant apo-proteins of GST-AmMT2 with Fe 2+ verified the presence of Fe 2+ -thiolate clusters ( Fig. 5A ). Compared to the apo-forms of GST-AmMT2, the proteins Fe 2+ /GST-AmMT2 showed increased absorbance at 314 nm typical of Fe 2+ containing proteins which confirms the binding of Fe 2+ to GST-AmMT
2 in
vitro. Moreover the ability of GST-AmMT2 to bind Fe 2+ was also studied by using the DTNB assay ( Fig. 5B ). The initial velocity of GST-AmMT2 incubated with saturated concentration of Fe 2+ (Fe 2+ /GST-AmMT2) was lower than that from apo-forms of GST-AmMT2. This could be due to binding of Fe 2+ to GSTAmMT2 which causes in decrease of available titratable thiol content. Therefore the lower initial velocity of Fe 2+ /GST-AmMT 2 in reaction with DTNB confirmed the ability of GST-AmMT2 to bind Fe 2+ .

sec.title: 2.4. The tolerance of R-AmMT2 was enhanced in response to H 2 O 2 stress
sec.p:
The final cell densities (cell density after 12 h) of strains AmMT2 were similar to that from control when the strains were grown in the medium with no stress ( Fig. 6A ). However, in the presence of 2 mM H 2 O 2 whereas the density for control strain after 12 h reached 1.02, the density for strains R-AmMT2 was 1.37, respectively ( Fig. 6A ). These data show that the heterologous expression of GST-AmMT2 enhances the tolerance of
E. coli cells
to H 2 O 2 .

Since one of the important antioxidant enzymes that is activated in response to H 2 O 2 is CAT, the activity of CAT in control and R-AmMT2 strains was determined in the medium containing H 2 O 2 in
the presence or absence of IPTG . As shown in Fig. 6B the enzyme CAT was active in both control and R-AmMT 2 in the response to H 2 O 2 . The CAT activity in the control strain in the presence and absence of IPTG was almost similar which suggests that the expression of GST has not affected on the CAT activity. However in the strain R-AmMT2 the CAT activity is significantly (P <0.01) higher than that from control strain when IPTG was added and the protein GST-AmMT2 was expressed. Based on these results, it seems that one of the important reasons for enhancement of tolerance R-AmMT 2 in response to H 2 O 2 is the higher activity of CAT compared to control strain.

sec.title: 2.5. Addition of pure Fe 2+/ AmMT2 enhanced the activity of CAT in the E. coli extract
sec.p: The CAT activity was determined in the protein extract from control strain before and after addition of pure recombinant forms of Apo/GSTAmMT2 as well as Fe 2+ /GST-AmMT2. The CAT activity in the extract was 50 Umg −1 . This value did not change by the addition of Apo/GSTAmMT2 ( Fig. 7 ). However, the CAT activity was increased to 75.4 Umg −1 after additions of Fe 2+ /GST-AmMT2. These data may demonstrate that Fe 2+ /GST-AmMT2 behave as an activator for CAT by supplying Fe 2+ .

sec.title: 3. Discussion
4. Conclusion
sec.p:
Taken together the protein AmMT2 is a member of MT type 2 with the ability for binding to essential and non-essential metals. However the
E. coli cells
expressing GST-AmMT2 were significantly able to accumulate Fe 2+ more than other metals. The heterologous expression of AmMT2 confers tolerance to H 2 O 2 to
E. coli cells
by increasing the activity of CAT. It seems that AmMT2 might release Fe 2+ during oxidative stress and activate the enzymes such as CAT that requires Fe 2+ and thus trigger a Fe 2+ mediated antioxidant response.

sec.title: 5.1. Cloning of gene encoding AmMT2
sec.p: The gene encoding AmMT2 (NCBI accession number: AF333385.1) was synthesized and cloned in pUC57 between two restriction sites Eco RI and Hin dIII. For subcloning of gene in pET41a, the plasmid pUC57-AmMT2 was digested with Eco RI and Hin dIII and the digestion product was run on agarose gel. The fragment containing AmMT2 gene was isolated from the gel. The fragment was then ligated into pET-41a (Novagen) after linearization with Eco RI and Hin dIII using T4 ligase (Thermo Fisher Scientific). The new constructs were named pET41aAmMT2.

sec.title: 5.2. Heterologous expression of GST-AmMT2
sec.p:
The resulting construct pET41-AmMT2 was verified by sequencing and then introduced in
E . coli
protease-deficient strain Rosetta (DE3) for protein expression. The resulted strain was termed R-AmMT2. The control strain was also made by transferring plasmid pET41a without gene. The
E. coli cells
containing either pET41a (Control) or pET41aAmMT2 (R-AmMT2) were grown at 37 ° C in Luria-Bertani (LB) medium in the volume of 50 ml supplemented with 50 μg/ml kanamycin and 5 μg/ml chloramphenicol to an OD 600 of about 0.6. At this OD cultures were induced by 100 μM Isopropyl β-D-1-thiogalactopyranoside ( IPTG ). In addition the culture medium was supplemented with 0.6 mM ZnSO 4. 7 H 2 O 20 min after addition of IPTG . To confirm heterologous expression of the protein, 1 ml samples of culture medium were harvested by centrifugation 1, 2, 3 and 4 h after addition of IPTG and frozen at −80 ° C until use. The frozen pellets were resuspended in 250 μl pre-cold 10 mM Tris–HCl, pH 8.0, disrupted by mild sonication at 4 ° C and centrifugated at 12,000 g , for 20 min. The soluble proteins recovered in supernatant phase were analyzed by 12% SDS-PAGE and stained by Coomassie Brilliant Blue R-250 (
).

sec.title: 5.3. Large scale production of GST-AmMT2 and purification
sec.p: For large scale production of proteins the cells were grown in 500 ml of medium. Induction with Isopropyl β-d-1-thiogalactopyranoside ( IPTG ), and supplementation with 0.6 mM ZnSO 4. 7 H 2 O were performed as explained above. The cells from whole volume were harvested 4 h after addition of IPTG . The soluble proteins were extracted as explained above. For purification the extracted soluble proteins were applied on to His-Trap HP column (GE, Healthcare) preequilibrated with loading buffer (10 mM imidazole, 500 mM NaCl, 30 mM Tris–HCl, pH 8.0) and the bound proteins were eluted by 68.5–283 mM imidazole gradient. Aliquots of the protein fractions were analyzed by 12% SDS-PAGE and stained by Coomasie Brilliant Blue R-250. The pure fractions were pooled and transferred into 12 kDa molecular weight cutoff cellulose tubes (Sigma) and dialyzed against 10 mM Tris–HCl, pH 8.0, at 4 ° C overnight to remove imidazole and other salts. Protein concentrations were determined by Beer-Lambert law with the molar extinction coefficient of 44,537.5 and 49,382.5 for GST and GST-AmMT2 respectively.

sec.title: 5.4. Metal ion tolerance of transformed cells
sec.p: Tolerance of strains control and R-AmMT2 to metals in the growth medium was examined in concentrations of 0.9 mM CdCl 2 · H 2 O , 1 mM ZnSO 4 ·7 H 2 O , 2 mM CuSO 4 ·5 H 2 O , 2.5 mM NiCl 2.6 H 2 O , and (1–3 mM) FeSO 4. 7 H 2 O . For the analysis 5 ml of the overnight cultures of cells were inoculated in 80 ml of LB medium supplemented with desired antibiotics. The cultures were induced at OD 600 = 0.6 by addition of 0.1 mM of IPTG . After 20 min, the metals were added to the cultures. Bacterial growth was monitored up to 12 h by OD 600 measurements. The data represent the mean obtained from two independent experiments with two replicates. The means were compared with t -test: *p <0.05; **p <0.01.

sec.title: 5.5. Analysis of metal ion accumulation in transformed cells
sec.p:
The growth of cells, induction with IPTG , and supplementation with metals were performed as explained in part 2.3. For the analysis of metals, cells from 10 ml of culture at 0 (T0) and 6 h after metal addition (T1) were precipitated by centrifugation at
6000 g
for 20 min. The supernatant was analyzed for metals Zn 2+ , Cu 2+ , Ni 2+ , Cd 2+ and Fe 2+ using inductively coupled plasma atomic absorption spectroscopy (PerkinElmer Analyst 700). The metal concentration changes in the medium of strains control and R-AmMT2 between T1 and T0 (CT 0 -CT 1 ) was calculated. The data represent the mean ± SD obtained from two independent experiments with two replicates. The means were compared with t -test: *p <0.05; **p <0.01.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: 5.6. Tolerance of E. coli cells to H 2 O 2

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Overnight cultures of different strains were inoculated into 80 mL of LB medium with desired antibiotics and grown at 37 °C under agitation. Protein expression was induced at an A 600 of 0.6 by addition of 0.1 mM IPTG. After 20 min, culture flasks were supplemented with either 2 mM H 2 O 2 or 4% ethanol and bacterial growth was monitored by A 600 measurements at 1 h intervals up to 12 h. The data represent the mean ± SD obtained from two independent experiments with two replicates. The means were compared with t -test: *p <0.05; **p <0.01.

sec.title: 5.7. Determination of CAT activity in transgenic bacteria
5.8. Preparation of Fe 2+ /GST-AmMT2
sec.p:
The production and purification of recombinant GST-AmMT were performed as described above. The concentration of proteins was determined by Beer-Lambert law. Apo-proteins were prepared by the methods previously described (
). For preparation of apo-proteins, aliquots of 25 μM purified GST-MTs were acidified with HCl to pH 2.0 and the samples were then dialyzed against 0.1 N HCl, pH 2.0, to remove bound metal ions. Reconstitution with Fe 2+ was achieved by the addition of 10 mol equivalents of Fe 2+ followed by neutralization of the samples to pH 8.0 with 200 mM Tris. The unbound metals were removed by dialyzing against 10 mM Tris–HCl, pH 8.0, at 4 ° C overnight.

sec.title: 5.9. UV absorption spectra
sec.p: The absorption spectra of metal-incubated and apo-forms of GSTAmMT proteins were determined between 220 and 360 nmusing spectrophotometer (DU 530).

sec.title: 5.10. Reaction with DTNB
sec.p: For this reaction 1.5 nmol of each protein which were obtained by reconstitution of apo-form of GST-AmMT with Fe 2+ was diluted in 300 μl of 10 mM Tris–HCl, pH 8.0 and placed into aquartz cuvette. The reaction was started by addition of 75 nmol of 5, 5′-dithio-bis-[2-nitrobenzoic acid] (DTNB). The absorbance at 412 nm was recorded on the spectrophotometer for 60 min at 25 ° C , reflecting the formation of 2-nitro-5-thiobenzoic acid (TNB). A 300 μl of 10 mM Tris–HCl solution containing 75 nmol of DTNB was used as blank. The initial velocity was obtained from each curve of absorbance versus the reaction time (t, min).

sec.title: 5.11. The effect of pure Fe 2+ /GST-AmMT2 on the activity of CAT
sec.p: The soluble protein fraction was extracted from control strain that was grown in the presence of 2 mM H 2 O 2 . The activities of CAT in this extract were determined before and after addition of 2 μM Apo/GSTAmMT2 or Fe/GST-AmMT2 by the methods described above. The data represents the mean ± SD obtained from two independent experiments with two replicates. The means were compared with least significant difference test (LSD, P 0.01) test.
Compliance with ethical standards
The authors declare that they have no conflict of interest.
Acknowledgement
Iran National Science Foundation is thanked for financial support (grant No. 97000792).
